And now to turn late promises to good effect,
Be thou Erastus governor of Rhodes,
by this thou shalt dismiss my garrison.

sp.speaker: Brus.
sp.l: Must he reap that for which I took the toil?
Come envy then and sit in friendship's seat,
How can I love him that enjoys my right.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Give me a crown, to crown the bride withal,
Perseda, for my sake wear this crown:
Now is she fairer than she was before,
This title so augments her beauty as the fire,
That lay with honour's hand racked up in ashes,
Revives again to flames, the force is such,
Remove the cause, and then the effect will die,
They must depart, or I shall not be quiet,
Erastus and Perseda, marvel not,
That all in haste I wish you to depart,
There is an urgent cause, but privy to myself,
Command my shipping for to waft you over.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: My gracious lord, when Erastus doth forget this favour,
Then let him live abandoned and forlorn.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: Nor will Perseda slack even in her prayers
And still solicit God for Soliman,
Whose mind hath proved so good and gracious.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Farewell Erastus, Perseda farewell to.
Methinks I should not part with two such friends,
The one so renowned for arms and courtesy,
The other so adorned with grace and modesty:
Yet of the two Perseda moves me most,
Ay and so moves me, that I now repent,
That ere I gave away my hearts desire,
What was it but abuse of fortune's gift,
And therefore fortune now will be revenged.
What was it but abuse of love's command,
And therefore mighty love will be revenged:
What was it but abuse of heavens that gave her me,
And therefore angry heavens will be revenged:
Heavens, love, and fortune, all three have decreed,
That I shall love her still, and lack her still,
like ever thirsting wretched Tantalus:
Foolish Soliman, why did I strive,
To do him kindness, and undo myself?
Well governed friends do first regard themselves.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I now occasion serves to stumble him,
That thrust his sickle in my harvest corn,
Pleaseth your majesty to hear Brusor speak.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: To one past cure, good counsel comes too late,
Yet say thy mind.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: With secret letters woe her, and with gifts,

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: My lines and gifts will but return my shame.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Hear me my lord, let me go over to Rhodes,
That I may plead in your affection's cause,
One woman may do much to win another.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Indeed Lucina were her husband from her,
She happily might be won by thy persuades,
But whilst he lives there is no hope in her.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why lives he then to grieve great Soliman,
This only remains, that you consider,
In two extremes the least is to be chosen,
If so your life depend upon her love,
And that her love depends upon his life,
Is it not better that Erastus die
Ten thousand deaths, than Soliman should perish?

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: I saist thou so? why then it shall be so,
But by what means shall poor Erastus die?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: This shall be the means,
I'll fetch him back again,
Under colour of great consequence,
No sooner shall he land upon our shore,
But witness shall be ready to accuse him,
Of treason done against your mightiness,
And then he shall be doomed by martial law,

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: O fine device, Brusor get thee gone,
Come thou again, but let the lady stay,
To win Perseda to my will, meanwhile ,
Will I prepare the judge and witnesses,
and if this take effect, thou shalt be viceroy,
And fair Lucina Queen of Tripoli,
Brusor be gone, for till thou come I languish.
And now to ease my troubled thoughts at last,
I will go sit among my learned eunuchs,
And here them play, and see my minions dance,
For till that Brusor bring me my desire,
I may assuage, but never quench love's fire.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: Since the expugnation of the Rhodian I'll,
Methinks a thousand years are overpast,
More for the lack of my Perseda's presence,
Than for the loss of Rhodes that paltry I'll,
Or for my friends that there were murdered,
My valour everywhere shall purchase friends,
And where a man lives well, there is his country.
Alas the Christians are but very shallow,
In giving judgement of a man at arms,
A man of my desert and excellence.
The Turks whom they account for barbarous,
Having foreheared of Basilisco's worth,
A number under prop me with their shoulders,
And in procession bore me to the church,
As I had been a second Mahomet,
I fearing they would adore me for a God,
Wisely informed them that I was but man,
Although in time perhaps I might aspire,
To purchase godhead, as did Hercules,
I mean by doing wonders in the world:
A midst their church they bound me to a pillar,
And to make trial of my valiancy,
They lopped a collop of my tenderest member.
But think you basilisk squicht for that,
Even as a cow for tickling in the horn,
That done, they set me on a milk white ass,
Compassing me with goodly ceremonies,
that day methought , I sat in Pompey's chair,
And viewed the Capitol, and was Rome's greatest glory.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: I would my master had left
Some other to be his agent here:
Faith I am weary of the office already,
What signior Tremomundo,
That rid a pilgrimage to beg cakebread.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O take me not unprovided, let me fetch my weapons.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Why I meant nothing but a basolus manus.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: No, didst thou not mean to give me the privy stab?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: No by my troth sir.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Nay if thou hadst, I had not feared thee I,
I tell thee my skin holds out pistol proof.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Pistol proof? I'll try if it will hold out pin prove,
sp.stage: Then he pricks him with a pin.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O shoot no more great God I yield to thee.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: I see his skin is but pistol proof from the girdle upward
What sudden agony was that?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Why sawest thou not, how Cupid God of love,
Not daring look me in the martial face,
Came like a coward stealing after me,
And with his pointed dart pricked my posteriors.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Then here my opinion concerning that point,
The ladies of Rhodes hearing that you have lost,
A capitol part of your lady ware,
Have made their petition to Cupid,
To plague you above all other,
As one prejudicial to their muliebrity,
Now sir, Cupid seeing you already hurt before,
Thinks it a greater punishment to hurt you behind,
Therefore I would wish you to have an eye to the back door

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Sooth thou sayest, I must be fenced behind,
I'll hang my target there.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Indeed that will serve to bear of some blows,
When you run away in a fray.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah, what art thou?
That thus encroachest upon my familiarity,
Without special admittance.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Why do you not know me? I am Erastus' man.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: What art thou that petty pigmy,
That challenged me at Rhode;:
Whom I refused to combat for his minority,
Where is Erastus I owe him chastisement in Perseda's quarrel.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Do not you know that they are all friends,
And Erastus married to Perseda,
And Erastus made governor of Rhodes,
And I left here to be their agent?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O coelum, o terra, o maria Neptune,
Did I turn Turk to follow her so far,

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: The more shame for you.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: And is she linked in liking with my foe?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: That's because you were out of the way.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O wicked Turk for to steal her hence.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: O wicked turn coat that would have her stay.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: The truth is, I'll be a Turk no more.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: And I fear thou wilt never prove good christian.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I will after to take revenge.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: And I'll stay here about my master's business.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Farewell Constantinople, I will to Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Farewell counterfeit fool,
God send him good shipping:
'Tis noised about, that Brusor is sent,
To fetch my master back again,
I cannot be well till I hear the rest of the news,
Therefore I'll about it straight.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Now fortune what hast thou done in this latter act?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: I brought Perseda to the presence,
Of Soliman the Turkish emperor,
And gave Lucina into Brusor's hands.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: And first I stung them with consenting love,
And made great Soliman sweet beauty's thrall,
Humble himself at fair Perseda's feet,
and made him praise love and captives beauty:
Again, I made him to recall his passions,
And give Perseda to Erastus hands,
And after make repentance of the deed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Mean time I filled Erastus sails with wind,
And brought him home unto his native land.

sp.speaker: Death.
sp.l: And I suborned Brusor with envious rage,
To counsel Soliman to slay his friend,
Brusor is sent to fetch him back again,
Mark well what follows, for the history
Proves me chief actor in this tragedy.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: Perseda, these days are our days of joy.
What could I more desire than thee to wife,
And that I have: or then to govern Rhodes,
And that I do, thanks to great Soliman,

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: And thanks to gracious heavens, that so
Brought Soliman from worse to better,
For though I never told it thee till now,
His heart was purposed once to do thee wrong.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: I that was before he knew thee to be mine,
But now Perseda, let's forget old griefs,
And let our studies wholly be employed,
To work each others bliss and hearts delight.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Our present joys will be so much the greater,
Whenas we call to mind fore passed griefs,
So sings the mariner upon the shore,
When he hath passed the dangerous time of storms:
But if my love will have old griefs forgotten,
They shall lie buried in Perseda's breast.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: Welcome lord Brusor.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: And Lucina to.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thanks lord governor.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: And thanks to you madam.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: What hasty news brings you so soon to Rhodes?
Although to me you never come to soon.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: So it is my lord, that upon great affairs,
Importuning health and wealth of Soliman,
His highness by me intreateth you,
As ever you respect his future love,
Or have regard unto his courtesy,
To come yourself in person and visit him,
Without inquiry what should be the cause.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: Were there no ships to cross the seas withal,
My arms should frame mine oars to cross the seas,
And should the seas turn tide to force me back.
Desire should frame me wings to fly to him,
I go Perseda thou must give me leave.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: Though loath, yet Soliman's command prevails,

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: And sweet Perseda I will stay with you,
From Brusor my beloved, and I'll want him,
Till he bring back Erastus unto you.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: Lord Brusor come 'tis time that we were gone.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Perseda farewell, be not angry,
For that I carry thy beloved from thee,
We will return with all speed possible,
And thou Lucina, use Perseda so,
That for my carrying of Erastus hence,
She curse me not, and so farewell to both.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Come Lucina let's in, my heart is full.

div.stage: Enter Soliman, lord marshal, the two witnesses, and janissaries.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Lord marshal, see you handle it cunningly,
And when Erastus comes our perjured friend,
See he be condemned by martial law,
Here will I stand to see and not be seen.

sp.speaker: Marshal.
sp.l: Come fellows see when this matter comes in question,
You stagger not: and janissaries,
See that your strangling cords be ready.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Ah that Perseda were not half so fair,
or that Soliman were not so fond,
Or that Perseda had some other love,
Whose death might save my poor Erastus' life,
See where he comes, whom though I dear love,
Yet must his blood be spilt for my behoof,
Such is the force of morrow burning love.

sp.speaker: Marshal.
sp.l: Erastus, lord governor of Rhodes,
I arrest you in the King's name.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: What thinks lord Brusor of this strange arrest,
Hast thou entrapped me to this treachery:
Intended well I wot without the leave
Or licence of my lord great Soliman.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why then appeal to him, where thou shalt know
And be assured that I betray thee not.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Yes, thou, and I, and all of us betray him.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: No, no, in this case no appeal shall serve.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Why then to thee, or unto any else,
I here protest by heavens unto you all,
That never was there man more true or just,
Or in his deeds more loyal and upright,
Or more loving, or more innocent,
Than I have been to gracious Soliman,
Since first I set my feet on Turkish land.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Myself would be his witness if I durst,
But bright Perseda's beauty stops my tongue.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: Why sirs, why face to face express you not,
The treasons you revealed to Soliman?

sp.speaker: Witnesses.
sp.l: That very day Erastus went from hence,
He sent for me into his cabinet,
And for that man that is of my profession.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: I never saw them I until this day.

sp.speaker: Witness.
sp.l: His cabin door fast shut, he first began
To question us of all sorts of fireworks,
Wherein, when we had fully resolved him,
What might be done, he spreading on the board,
A huge heap of our imperial coin,
all this is yours quoth he, if you consent,
To leave great Soliman and serve in Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: Why that was treason, but onwards with the rest.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: What have we here, my master before the marshal?

sp.speaker: Witn.
sp.l: We said not I, nor durst we say him nay,
Because we were already in his galleys,
But seemed content to fly with him to Rhodes,
With that he pursed the gold, and gave it us.
The rest I dare not speak it is so bad.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: Heavens hear you this, and drops not vengeance on them
The other wit. The rest, and worst, will I discourse in brief,
Will you consent quoth he to fire the fleet,
That lies hard by us here in Bosphoron,
For be it spoke in secret here quoth he,
Rhodes must no longer bear the Turkish yoke,
We said the task might easily be performed,
But that we lacked such drugs to mix with powder,
As were not in his galleys to be got,
At this he leapt for joy, swearing and promising,
That our reward should be redoubled:
We came a-land not minding for to return,
And as our duty and allegiance bound us,
We made all known unto great Soliman,
But ere we could summon him a land,
His ships were passed a kenning from the shore,
Belike he thought we had bewrayed his treasons.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: That all is true that here you have declared.
Both lay your hands upon the Alcaron.

sp.speaker: 1. wit
sp.l: Foul death betide me if I swear not true,

sp.speaker: 2. wit
sp.l: And mischief light on me, if I swear false.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Mischief and death shall light upon you both.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: Erastus thou seest what witness hath produced against thee,
What answerest thou unto their accusations?

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: That these are Sinon's and myself poor Troy.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: Now it resteth, I appoint thy death,
Wherein thou shalt confess I'll favour thee,
for that thou wert beloved of Soliman,
Thou shalt forthwith be bound unto that post,
And strangled as our Turkish order is.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Such favour send all Turks I pray God.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: I see this train was plotted ere I came,
What boots complaining where's no remedy:
Yet give me leave before my life shall end,
To moan Perseda, and accuse my friend.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: O unjust Soliman, oh wicked time,
Where filthy lust must murder honest love.

sp.speaker: Marshal
sp.l: Dispatch, for our time limited is past.

sp.speaker: Erast.
sp.l: Alas, how can he but be short, whose tongue
Is fast tide with galling sorrow.
Farewell Perseda, no more but that for her:
Inconstant Soliman, no more but that for him,
Unfortunate Erastus, no more but that for me:
Lo this is all, and thus I leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Marry sir this is a fair warning for me to get me gone.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: O save his life, if it be possible,
I will not lose him for my kingdom's worth,
Ah poor Erastus art thou dead already,
What bold presumer durst be so resolved,
For to bereave Erastus' life from him,
Whose life to me was dearer than mine own,
Wast thou and thou, lord marshal bring them hither ,
And at Erastus' hand let them receive,
The stroke of death, whom they have spoilt of life:
What is thy hand too weak? than mine shall help,
To send them down to everlasting night,
To wait upon thee through eternal shade,
Thy soul shall not go mourning hence alone:
Thus die and thus, for thus you murdered him,
sp.stage: Then he kills the two janissaries, that killed Erastus,
sp.l: But soft methinks he is not satisfied,
The breath doth murmur softly from his lips,
And bids me kill those bloody witnesses,
by whose treachery Erastus died:
Lord Marshall, hale them to the tower's top,
And throw them headlong down into the valley,
So let their treasons with their lives have end.

sp.speaker: 1. Witn.
sp.l: Yourself procured us.

sp.speaker: 2. Witn.
sp.l: Is this our hire?
sp.stage: Then the marshal bears them to the tower top.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Speak not a word, lest in my wrathful fury,
I doom you to ten thousand direful torments:
And Brusor see Erastus be interred,
With honour in a kingly sepulchre,
Why when lord marshal? great Hector's son,
Although his age did plead for innocence:
Was sooner tumbled from the fatal tower.
Than are those perjured wicked witnesses.
sp.stage: Then they are both tumbled down.
sp.l: Why now Erastus' ghost is satisfied:
Ay, but yet the wicked judge survives,
By whom Erastus was condemned to die,
Brusor, as thou lovest me stab in the martial,
Lest he detect us unto the world,
By making known our bloody practises,
And then will thou and I hoist sail to Rhodes,
Where thy Lucina and my Perseda lives.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I will my lord: lord marshal, it is his highness' pleasure
That you commend him to Erastus' soul.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Here ends my dear Erastus' tragedy,
And now begins my pleasant comedy,
But if Perseda understand these news,
Our scene will prove but tragicomical.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Fear not my lord, Lucina plays her part,
And woos apace in Soliman's behalf.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Then Brusor come, and with some few men,
Let's sail to Rhodes with all convenient speed,
For till I fouled Perseda in mine arms,
My troubled ears are deft with love's alarms.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: Now signior Basilisco, which like you,
The Turkish or our nation best.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: That which your ladyship will have me like,

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I am deceived but you were circumcised,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Indeed I was a little cut in the purpose.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What means made you to steal back to Rhodes

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: The mighty pinckanied brand bearing God,
To whom I am so long true servitor,
When he espied my weeping floods of tears,
For your depart, he bade me follow him:
I followed him, he with his fire brand,
Parted the seas, and we came over dry-shod.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: A matter not unlikely: but how chance,
Your Turkish bonnet is not on your head?

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: Because I now am christian again,
And that by natural means, for as
The old cannon says very prettily,
Nihill est tam naturali, quod eo modo colligatum est.
And so forth: so I became a Turk to follow her,
To follow her, am now returned a christian.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: O lady and mistress, weep and lament,
And wring your hands, for my master
Is condemned and executed.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Be patient sweet Perseda, the fool but jests,

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: Ah ho, my nightly dreams foretold me this,
Which foolish woman fondly I neglected,
But say what death died my poor Erastus?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Nay, God be praised, his death was reasonable,
He was but strangled,

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: But strangled, ah double death to me,
But say, wherefore was he condemned to die?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: For nothing but high treason.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: What treason, or by whom was he condemned?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Faith two great knights of the post, swore upon the
Alcaron, that he would have fired the Turks fleet.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: Was Brusor by?

sp.speaker: Piston.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And Soliman?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: No but I saw where he stood,
To here and see the matter well conveyed.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: Accursed Soliman, profane Alcaron,
Lucina, came thy husband to this end?
To lead a lamb unto the slaughterhouse,
Hast thou for this, in Soliman's behalf?
With cunning words tempted my chastity,
Thou shalt aby for both your treacheries,
It must be so, Basilisco dost thou love me, speak,

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: I more than I love either life or soul,
What shall I stab the emperor for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: No, but Lucina if thou lovest me, kill her,
sp.stage: Then Basilisco takes a dagger and feels upon the point of it.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: The point will mar her skin.

sp.speaker: Perse,
sp.l: What darest thou not, give me the dagger then,
There's a reward for all thy treasons past,

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: Yet dare I bear her hence, to do thee good.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: No let her lie, a prey to ravening birds:
Nor shall her death alone suffice for his,
Rhodes now shall be no longer Soliman's,
We'll fortify our walls, and keep the town,
In spite of proud insulting Soliman,
I know the lecher hopes to have my love,
And first Perseda, shall with this hand die,
Then yield to him and live in infamy.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: I will ruminate. Death which the poets
Fain to be pale and meager;
Hath deprived Erastus' trunk from breathing vitality,
A brave cavalier, but my approved foeman:
Let me see: where is that Alcides, surnamed Hercules?
The only club man of his time: dead.
Where is the eldest son of Priam?
That Abraham coloured troion: dead.
Where is the leader of the Myrmidons,
That well knit Achill: dead.
Where is that furious Aiax, the son of Telamon,
Or that fraudful squire of Ithaca, yclept Ulysses? dead,
Where is tipsy Alexander, that great cup conqueror,
Or Pompey that brave warrior? dead:
I am myself strong, but I confess death to be stronger,
I am valiant, but mortal,
I am a with nature's gifts,
A giddy goddess, that now giveth and anon taketh,
I am wise, but quiddits will not answer death:
To conclude in a word, to be captious virtuous, ingenious,
Or to be nothing when it pleaseth death to be envious.
The great Turk, whose seat is Constantinople,
Hath beleaguered Rhodes, whose chieftain is a woman.
I could take the rule upon me,
But the shrub is safe when the cedar shaketh:
I love Perseda as one worthy,
But I love Basilisco as one I hold more worthy.
My father's son, my mother's solace, my proper self.
Faith he can do little that cannot speak,
And he can do less that cannot run away.
Then sith man's life is as a glass, and a fillip may crack it,
Mine is no more and a bullet may pierce it:
Therefore I will play lest in sight.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: The gates are shut, which proves that Rhodes revolts,
And that Perseda is not Soliman's.
Ah Brusor see where thy Lucina lies
Butchered despitefully without the walls.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Unkind Perseda, couldst thou use her so?
And yet we used Perseda little better.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Nay gentle Brusor stay thy tears a while,
Lest with thy woes thou spoil my comedy,
And all to soon be turned to tragedies.
Go Brusor, bear her to thy private tent,
Where we at leisure will lament her death,
and with our tears be wail her obsequies:
For yet Perseda lives for Soliman.
Drum sound a parle, were it not for her,
I would sack the town ere I would sound a parley.

div.stage: The drum sounds a parley. Perseda comes upon the walls in man's apparel Basilisco and Piston upon the walls.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: At whose entreaty is this parley sounded?

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: At our entreaty, therefore yield the town.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why what art thou that boldly bids us yield?

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Great Soliman, lord of all the world.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou art not lord of all, Rhodes is not thine.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: It was, and shall be maugre who says no.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I that say no will never see it thine.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Why what art thou that dares resist my force?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A gentleman and thy mortal enemy,
And one that dares thee to the single combat:

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: First tell me, doth Perseda live or no?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She lives to see the wrack of Soliman,

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Then I'll combat thee whate'er thou art.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And in Erastus' name I'll combat thee,
And here I promise thee on my Christian faith,
Then will I yield Perseda to thy hands.
That if thy strength shall over match my right,
To use, as to thy liking shall seem best,
But ere I come to enter single fight,
First let my tongue utter my heart's despite,
And thus my tale begins: thou wicked tyrant,
Thou murderer, accursed homicide,
For whom hell gapes, and all the ugly fiends
Do wait for to receive thee in their jaws:
Ah perjured and in human Soliman,
How could thy heart harbour a wicked thought?
Against the spotless life of poor Erastus?
Was he not true? would thou hadst been as just,
Was he not valiant? would thou hadst been as virtuous,
Was he not loyal? would thou hadst been as loving:
ah wicked tyrant in that one man's death,
Thou hast betrayed the flower of Christendom ,
Died he because his worth obscured thine,
In slaughtering him thy virtues are defamed,
Didst thou misdo him, in hope to win Perseda,
Ah foolish man, therein thou art deceived,
For though she live, yet will she ne'er live thine,
Which to approve, I'll come to combat thee.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Injurious foul mouthed knight, my wrathful arm
Shall chastise and rebuke these injuries.

div.stage: Then Perseda comes down to Soliman, and Basilisco and Piston.

sp.speaker: Pist
sp.l: Ay but hear you, are you so foolish to fight with him?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I sirrah, why not, as long as I stand by?

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: I'll not defend Erastus' innocence,
But thee, maintaining of Perseda's beauty,

div.stage: Then they fight, Soliman kills Perseda.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I now I lay Perseda at thy feet,
But with thy hand first wounded to the death,
Now shall the world report that Soliman,
Slew Erastus in hope to win Perseda,
And murdered her for loving of her husband.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: What my Perseda, ah what have I done,
Yet kiss me gentle love before thou die.

sp.speaker: Perse.
sp.l: A kiss I grant thee, though I hate thee deadly,

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: I loved thee dear and accept thy kiss,
Why didst thou love Erastus more than me,
Or why didst not give Soliman a kiss
Ere this unhappy time, than hadst thou lived:

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: Ah let me kiss thee too before I die,

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Nay die thou shalt for thy presumption,
For kissing her whom I do hold so dear,

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: I will not kiss her sir, but give me leave
To weep over her, for while she lived,
She loved me dear, and I loved her.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: If thou didst love her villain as thou saidst,
then wait on her through eternal night.
Ah Perseda, how shall I mourn for thee?
Fair springing rose, ill plucked before thy time.
Ah heavens that hitherto have smiled on me,
Why do you unkindly lower on Soliman?
The loss of half my realms, nay crowns decay,
Could not have pricked so near unto my heart,
As doth the loss of my Perseda's life:
And with her life, I likewise lose my love,
And with her love my heart's felicity,
Even for Erastus' death, the heavens have plagued me.
Ah no the heavens did never more accurse me,
Than when they made me butcher of my love,
Yet justly how can I condemn myself,
When Brusor lives that was the cause of all.
Come Brusor, help to lift her body up,
Is she not fair?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Even in the hour of death.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Was she not constant?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: As firm as are the poles whereon heaven lies.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Was she not chaste?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: As is Pandora or Diana's thoughts.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Then tell me? his treasons set aside,
What was Erastus in thy opinion?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Fair spoken, wise, courteous, and liberal:
Kind, even to his foes, gentle and affable,
And all, in all, his deeds heroical.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Ah, was he so? how durst thou then ungracious counsellor,
First cause me murder such a worthy man,
And after tempt so virtuous a woman,
Be this therefore the last that ere thou speak:
Janissaries, take him straight unto the block,
Off with his head, and suffer him not to speak.
And now Perseda here I lay me down,
And on thy beauty still contemplate,
until mine eyes shall surfeit by my gazing:
But stay let me see what paper is this.
sp.stage: Then he takes up a paper, and redes in it as followeth.
sp.l: Tyrant my lips were sawest with deadly poison,
To plague thy heart that is so full of poison.
What am I poisoned? then janissaries,
Let me see Rhodes recovered ere I die,
Soldiers, assault the town on every side,
Spoil all, kill all, let none escape your fury,
sp.stage: Sound an alarum to the fight.
sp.l: Say captain, is Rhodes recovered again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It is my lord, and stoops to Soliman.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.l: Yet that alleys the fury of my pain,
Before I die, for doubtless die I must,
I fates, injurious fates, have so decreed,
For now I feel the poison begins to work,
And I am weak even to the very death,
Yet some thing more contentedly I die,
For that my death was wrought by her device,
Who living was my joy, whose death my woe.
Ah janissaries now dies your emperor,
Before his age hath seen his mellowed years,
And if you ever loved your emperor,
Affright me not with sorrows and laments,
And when my soul from body shall depart,
Trouble me not but let me pass in peace,
And in your silence let your love be shown:
My last request for I command no more,
Is that my body, with Perseda's be,
Interred, where my Erastus lies entombed,
And let one epitaph contain us all:
Ah now I feel the paper told me true,
The poison is dispersed through every vain,
And boils like Aetna in my frying guts,
Forgive me dear Erastus my unkindness:
I have revenged thy deaths with many deaths,
And sweet Perseda fly not Soliman,
Whenas my gliding ghost shall follow thee,
With eager mood, thorough eternal night:
And now pale death sits on my panting soul,
And with revenging ire doth tyrannize:
And says for Soliman's too much amiss,
This day shall be the period of my bliss.
sp.stage: Then Soliman dies, and they carry him forth with silence.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: I gave Erastus woe and misery,
Amid his greatest joy and jollity.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: But I that have power in earth and heaven above,
Stung them both with never failing love.

sp.speaker: Death.
sp.l: But I bereft them both of love and life.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Of life, but not of love, for even in death,
Their souls are knit, though bodies be disjoined,
Thou didst but wound their flesh, their minds are free,
Their bodies buried, yet they honour me.

sp.speaker: Death.
sp.l: Hence foolish fortune, and thou wanton love,
Your deeds are trifles, mine of consequence,

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: I give world's happiness, and woes increase.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: By joining persons, I increase the world.

sp.speaker: Death.
sp.l: By wastning all, I conquer all the world,
And now to end our difference at last,
In this last act, note but the deeds of death,
Where is Erastus now but in my triumph?
Where are the murderers but in my triumph?
Where's judge and witness but in my triumph?
Where's false Lucina but in my triumph?
Where's fair Perseda but in my triumph?
Where's Basilisco but in my triumph?
Where's faithful Piston but in my triumph?
Where's valiant Brusor but in my triumph?
And where's great Soliman but in my triumph?
Their loves and fortunes ended with their lives,
and they must wait upon the car of death:
Pack love and fortune, play in comedies,
For powerful death best fitteth tragedies.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I go, yet love shall never yield to death.

sp.speaker: Death.
sp.l: But fortune shall, for when I waste the world,
Than times and kingdom's fortunes shall decay.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Mean time will fortune govern as she may.

sp.speaker: Death.
sp.l: I now will death in his most haughty pride,
Fetch his imperial car from deepest hell,
And ride in triumph through the wicked world,
Sparing none but sacred Cynthia's friend,
Whom death did fear before her life began,
For holy fates have graven it in their tables,
That death shall die if he attempt her end,
Whose life is heaven's delight and Cynthia's friend.

div.p: Imprinted at London for Edward white, and are to be sold at his shop, at the little North door of s. Paul's church at the sign of the gunne..

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
